whyYouShouldInvest.title: üí∞ Why You Need to Invest
whyYouShouldInvest.subtitle: Your Journey to Financial Freedom Starts Here
whyYouShouldInvest.description: You don't need to be rich to start investing. But if you never start, it will be much harder to ever get rich.

realityCheck.title: ü§î Let's Start with a Reality Check
realityCheck.content: Imagine you have $10,000 sitting in your savings account earning 0.5% interest. Now imagine your friend invested the same amount and earned 7% annually. After 30 years, you'd have $11,617. Your friend? $76,123. That's the power of compound interest.
realityCheck.button: Click to see what happens to $10,000 over 20 years
realityCheck.conclusion: That's enough to buy a car, pay for a wedding, or fund a year of living expenses! This is why every financial expert says the same thing: time in the market beats timing the market.

compoundInterest.title: üìà The Magic of Compound Interest
compoundInterest.content: Compound interest is when you earn interest on your interest. It's like a snowball rolling down a hill - it starts small but grows bigger and bigger over time. The earlier you start, the more powerful it becomes.

inflation.title: üí∏ The Silent Thief: Inflation
inflation.content: Inflation erodes the purchasing power of your money over time. If inflation is 3% per year, your $100 today will only be worth $97 next year. Investing helps your money grow faster than inflation, preserving and increasing your purchasing power.
inflation.warning: The brutal truth: If you're not investing, you're actually losing money every year.
inflation.example: With average inflation at 3% annually, money that sits in cash loses purchasing power over time. For example, $10,000 today would only buy about $7,400 worth of goods in 10 years if prices rise ~3% per year.
inflation.conclusion: This is why investing matters: your money needs to grow just to maintain its value.

threePillars.title: üéØ The Three Pillars of Why You Must Invest

pillars.title: 1. Beat Inflation (Survival Mode)
pillars.description: If you're not investing, you're actually losing money every year. With average inflation at 3%, your $1,000 today will only buy $744 worth of goods in 10 years. Your money needs to grow just to maintain its value.

pillars.title: 2. Build Wealth (Growth Mode)
pillars.description: The stock market has historically returned about 10% annually over the long term. That means your money can double approximately every 7 years through compound growth. Einstein allegedly called compound interest 'the eighth wonder of the world' ‚Äì and for good reason.

pillars.title: 3. Achieve Financial Freedom (Freedom Mode)
pillars.description: When your investments generate enough passive income to cover your living expenses, you've achieved financial independence. You're no longer trading time for money ‚Äì your money works for you 24/7.

items.myth: I don't have enough money to start investing
items.reality: You can start investing with as little as $1. Many brokerages now offer fractional shares, meaning you can own a piece of expensive stocks like Amazon or Tesla with just a few dollars.
Not investing is riskier. Inflation guarantees you'll lose purchasing power. While investments can fluctuate, historically they've been the best way to grow wealth over time.

items.myth: I need to be a financial expert
items.reality: You need basic knowledge, not a finance degree. Index funds allow you to invest in hundreds of companies with zero stock-picking skills required.

items.myth: I'll start investing when I'm older and make more money
items.reality: Starting early is your biggest advantage. A 25-year-old investing $200/month until retirement will likely have more money than a 35-year-old investing $400/month, thanks to compound interest.

earlyStart.title: üìä The Power of Starting Early
earlyStart.description: Starting early gives compound growth more time to work. Even small amounts invested consistently over many years can significantly outperform larger amounts invested later.

scenarios.title: Scenario A - Early Bird
details: Invests $200 monthly for 10 years, then stops

earlyStart.conclusion: The early bird invested $48,000 less but ended up with $146,000 more! That's the magic of compound interest combined with time.

quiz.title: üß† Quick Knowledge Check
quiz.question: What is compound interest?

options.text: Interest earned only on the principal amount
Interest earned on both principal and previously earned interest
Interest earned only on previously earned interest

quiz.correctAnswer: B) Interest earned on both principal and previously earned interest
quiz.explanation: Compound interest is the magic of investing - you earn returns on your returns, creating exponential growth over time.

questions.question: What is compound interest?
options: Interest earned only on the principal amount
Interest earned on both principal and previously earned interest
Interest earned only on previously earned interest

questions.question: Why is starting to invest early important?
options: Compound interest has more time to work

keyTakeaways.title: üéâ Key Takeaways
items: Compound interest is your greatest wealth-building tool - start early!
Inflation erodes purchasing power - investing beats inflation
Time in the market beats timing the market
You don't need to be rich to start investing - start with what you have
The earlier you start, the more powerful compound interest becomes

nextSteps.title: Next Steps
nextSteps.description: Now that you understand why investing is crucial, let's set your first financial goal and create a roadmap to achieve it.
nextSteps.lessonLabel: Lesson 1 of 4 ‚Äî "Complete! You've mastered the fundamentals."
nextSteps.completeMessage: Remember: The best time to start investing was 20 years ago. The second best time is now.

setFinancialGoal.title: üéØ Set Your Financial Goal
setFinancialGoal.subtitle: Define Your Path to Financial Success
setFinancialGoal.description: Every successful investment journey starts with a clear goal. Let's define yours and create a roadmap to achieve it.

importance.title: üéØ Why Goals Matter
importance.content: Without a clear goal, investing becomes aimless. A well-defined financial goal gives you direction, motivation, and a way to measure your progress. Whether it's buying a house, retiring comfortably, or building wealth, your goal shapes your investment strategy.

types.title: üìã Types of Financial Goals
types.content: Financial goals typically fall into three categories: Short-term (1-3 years), Medium-term (3-10 years), and Long-term (10+ years). Each requires different investment strategies and risk levels.

calculator.title: üßÆ Calculate Your Goal
calculator.content: Use our Financial Independence Calculator to determine how much you need to save and invest to achieve your goal.

financialPlan.title: üó∫Ô∏è Why You Need a Financial Plan (Not Just Goals)
financialPlan.content: Most people set random financial goals: "save for retirement," "buy a house," "have an emergency fund." But these scattered goals often conflict with each other and lack a unifying purpose.
financialPlan.definition: A financial plan is different‚Äîit's your complete strategy for achieving financial independence
financialPlan.fiDefinition: Financial Independence (FI) = Having enough passive income to cover your lifestyle indefinitely

randomGoals.title: ‚ùå Random Goals Approach:
items: Conflicting priorities and timelines
No clear path to financial freedom
Reactive money management
Always chasing the next financial milestone

strategicPlan.title: ‚úÖ Strategic Financial Plan:
items: One clear destination: Financial Independence
All goals work together toward FI
Proactive wealth building strategy
Freedom to choose your life path

fiFramework.title: üí∞ The Financial Independence Framework
fiFramework.content: Financial Independence follows a simple mathematical formula that anyone can understand and implement:

steps.title: Step 3: Execute Plan
steps.formula: Automate investments, optimize taxes, track progress

savingsRates.title: The Magic of High Savings Rates:

fiCalculator.title: üßÆ Your Personal FI Calculator
fiCalculator.content: Let's calculate your personalized path to financial independence:

supportingGoals.title: üéØ Building Your Supporting Goals
supportingGoals.content: Once you have your FI plan, all other financial goals should support this primary objective. Here's how to structure your supporting goals:

fiFilter.title: üí° The FI Filter: Before Adding Any Goal, Ask:

planningProcess.title: üìã Your FI Planning Process
planningProcess.content: Creating a financial plan isn't a one-time activity. Here's your systematic approach:

tasks: Calculate your FI number and timeline
Set up automatic savings and investments
Consider house hacking or real estate

quiz.title: üß† Financial Plan Knowledge Check
quiz.question: What's the main advantage of having a financial independence plan versus scattered financial goals?

options.text: It's easier to achieve multiple small goals
All goals work together toward one unified objective
You can retire earlier than everyone else

quiz.correctAnswer: B) All goals work together toward one unified objective
quiz.explanation: A financial independence plan provides a unified framework where every financial decision supports your ultimate goal of FI. This eliminates conflicting priorities and ensures optimal resource allocation toward building wealth and achieving financial freedom.

thisWeek.title: This Week
tasks: Calculate your FI number using the 25x rule
Set your target FI age and timeline
Open a dedicated FI tracking spreadsheet

thisMonth.title: This Month
tasks: Automate investments toward your FI goal
Complete your emergency fund if needed

keyTakeaways.title: üéâ Key Takeaways
items: Financial independence is your north star‚Äîall goals should support it
Your FI number = Annual expenses √ó 25 (4% withdrawal rule)
Higher savings rate = Dramatically shorter timeline to FI
Automate everything‚Äîconsistency beats perfection every time
Use the FI filter‚Äîdoes this goal support or delay your independence?
Track progress monthly‚Äîwhat gets measured gets managed
Supporting goals should accelerate, not derail, your FI plan

nextSteps.title: Next Steps
nextSteps.description: Now that you have a clear financial independence plan, our next lesson will teach you the fundamentals of investing. You'll learn how to build the investment portfolio that will power your journey to FI.
nextSteps.lessonLabel: Lesson 2 of 4 ‚Äî "Complete! You've mastered financial planning."
nextSteps.completeMessage: Remember: Financial independence isn't about having millions‚Äîit's about having enough to choose how you spend your time.

investingBasics.title: üìà Investing Basics
investingBasics.subtitle: Your Complete Guide to Making Your Money Work for You
investingBasics.description: You now understand WHY you need to invest and WHAT you're investing for. Now comes the exciting part: HOW to actually make your money grow.

goalsToAction.title: üéØ From Goals to Action: Making the Connection
goalsToAction.content: Think of investing like planting a garden. You wouldn't throw seeds randomly in the dirt and hope for the best. You'd choose the right seeds (investments) for your climate (risk tolerance), plant them in good soil (diversified portfolio), water them regularly (consistent contributions), and give them time to grow.
goalsToAction.highlight: Today, you become a money gardener.

investmentUniverse.title: üèóÔ∏è The Investment Universe: Your Options Explained

stocks.title: Stocks (Equities)
stocks.what: You buy a tiny piece of ownership in a company
stocks.how: Company grows in value, stock price goes up + dividends
stocks.example: You buy Apple stock for $150. If Apple does well and the stock rises to $180, you made $30 per share. If Apple struggles, it might drop to $120, and you'd lose $30 per share.

bonds.title: Bonds (Fixed Income)
bonds.what: You loan money to a government or company
bonds.how: They pay you interest regularly, then return your principal
bonds.example: You buy a $1,000 government bond paying 4% annually for 10 years. You'll receive $40 per year for 10 years, then get your $1,000 back.

mutualFunds.title: Mutual Funds
mutualFunds.what: A basket containing many stocks, bonds, or both
mutualFunds.how: The fund's investments grow in value
mutualFunds.example: Instead of picking individual stocks, you buy shares in a fund that owns 500 different companies. If those companies do well on average, your fund value increases.

etfs.title: Exchange-Traded Funds (ETFs)
etfs.what: Like mutual funds but trade like stocks throughout the day
etfs.how: Same as mutual funds but often with lower fees
etfs.example: An S&P 500 ETF owns all 500 companies in that index. When you buy shares, you own a tiny piece of America's biggest companies.

riskReturn.title: ‚öñÔ∏è Risk vs. Return: The Golden Rule of Investing
riskReturn.fundamentalTruth: The fundamental truth: Higher potential returns come with higher risk. There's no free lunch in investing.

examples: Growth stocks: Can be much higher or lower

personalRiskTolerance.title: Your Personal Risk Tolerance
questions: Time horizon: How long until you need this money?
Sleep test: Would a 20% portfolio drop keep you awake at night?
Recovery ability: Can you make up losses with future earnings?
Experience: Are you comfortable with market volatility?

riskQuiz.title: üß† Risk Tolerance Quiz
riskQuiz.timeHorizonQuestion: What's your time horizon for this money?
riskQuiz.riskToleranceQuestion: How would you describe your risk tolerance?
riskQuiz.resultSuffix: Based on your age ({age}), time horizon ({timeHorizon} years), and risk tolerance ({riskTolerance}).

dcaSimulator.title: üöÄ Dollar-Cost Averaging: Your Secret Weapon
dcaSimulator.description: Dollar-Cost Averaging (DCA) means investing the same amount of money at regular intervals, regardless of market conditions.
dcaSimulator.whyDcaWorks: Why DCA Works: You bought more shares when prices were low ($80) and fewer when prices were high ($120), resulting in a lower average cost per share than if you had invested all at once.

options.title: Option A - Simple Three-Fund Portfolio
items: 70% Total Stock Market Index Fund (like VTI)
20% International Stock Index Fund (like VTIAX)
10% Bond Index Fund (like BND)

options.title: Option B - Target-Date Fund
items: One fund that automatically adjusts
Based on your retirement date
Gets more conservative as you age
Example: "2055 Target Date Fund"

options.title: Option C - Robo-Advisor
items: Automated investing service
Builds portfolio for you
Examples: Betterment, Wealthfront
Handles rebalancing automatically

mistakes.problem: Waiting for the "perfect" time to invest
Most professionals can't beat the market consistently

mistakes.solution: Check monthly or quarterly at most

mistakes.mistake: Not Having an Emergency Fund First
mistakes.problem: You might need to sell investments at a loss
mistakes.solution: Build 3-6 months expenses in cash first

mistakes.problem: By the time you hear about it, it's often too late

quiz.title: üß† Knowledge Check Quiz
quiz.question: What's the most important factor in determining your asset allocation?

options.text: How much money you have to invest
What your friends are investing in

quiz.correctAnswer: B) Your age and time horizon
quiz.explanation: Your age and time horizon are the most important factors because they determine how much risk you can afford to take. Younger investors can handle more risk because they have time to recover from market downturns.

keyTakeaways.title: üéâ Key Takeaways
items: Start simple - Index funds and ETFs are perfect for beginners
Diversify broadly - Don't put all money in one investment
Match risk to timeline - Longer goals can handle more risk
Automate everything - Remove emotions from the equation
Stay the course - Time in the market beats timing the market
Keep costs low - Fees compound against you over time
Think decades, not days - Successful investing is boring

nextSteps.title: Next Steps
nextSteps.description: Now that you understand the basics of investing, our next lesson will teach you how to actually build your first portfolio. You'll learn specific fund recommendations, how to allocate your money, and how to put together a complete investment plan that matches your goals.
nextSteps.lessonLabel: Lesson 3 of 4 ‚Äî "Complete! You've mastered investing basics."
nextSteps.completeMessage: Remember: The best investment strategy is the one you can stick with. Don't let perfect be the enemy of good ‚Äì start investing today, even if it's not perfect.

buildPortfolio.title: üèóÔ∏è Build Your First Portfolio
buildPortfolio.subtitle: Turn Knowledge Into Action
buildPortfolio.description: Create a diversified portfolio that aligns with your goals and risk tolerance.

assetAllocation.title: üìä Asset Allocation
assetAllocation.content: Asset allocation is how you divide your investments among different asset classes like stocks, bonds, and cash. This is one of the most important decisions you'll make as an investor.

rebalancing.title: ‚öñÔ∏è Rebalancing
rebalancing.content: Over time, your portfolio's allocation will drift from your target. Rebalancing involves buying and selling to restore your desired allocation.

calculator.title: üßÆ Portfolio Calculator
calculator.content: Use our Portfolio Calculator to determine the optimal allocation for your risk tolerance and investment goals.

diversificationMatters.title: üéØ Why Diversification is Your Best Friend

concentrationProblem.title: The Problem with Concentration
items: Putting all money in one stock = huge risk
Even Apple fell 76% in 2000-2002
Single countries can underperform for decades
Bonds and stocks often move opposite directions

diversificationPower.title: The Power of Diversification
items: Spreads risk across thousands of companies
Captures global economic growth
Smooths out volatility over time
Ensures you never miss the next big winner

historicalEvidence.title: üìä Historical Evidence
historicalEvidence.content: A globally diversified portfolio has never had a negative 20-year return in modern history, while individual stocks and sectors can go to zero.

domesticStocks.title: üá∫üá∏ ITOT - US Total Market
domesticStocks.role: Core holding for developed market stability and growth

internationalStocks.title: üåç VXUS - International Stocks
internationalStocks.role: Hedges against US-only risk, captures global growth

domesticBonds.title: üèõÔ∏è AGG - US Total Bond Market
domesticBonds.whyThisFund: Broad bond exposure, 0.03% fee, high quality
domesticBonds.role: Stability during stock market crashes, income generation

internationalBonds.title: üåê BNDX - International Bonds
internationalBonds.role: Hedges US dollar risk, international stability
alternatives: Skip it: Many experts suggest US bonds only
VTEB (Vanguard Tax-Exempt) if in high tax bracket

threeFund.title: üéØ Three-Fund Portfolio
threeFund.bestFor: Perfect for beginners who want simplicity

steps.title: Choose Your Brokerage
steps.content: Fidelity, Vanguard, or Schwab all offer commission-free ETF trades. Pick one and open a Roth IRA or taxable account.

steps.title: Fund Your Account
steps.content: Set up automatic monthly transfers from your bank. Start with whatever you can afford - even $50/month builds wealth over time.

steps.title: Buy Your First Shares
steps.content: Purchase ITOT, VXUS, AGG, and BNDX according to your target allocation. Many brokers offer fractional shares.

steps.title: Automate Everything
steps.content: Set up automatic investing to buy these four funds monthly. This removes emotion and timing mistakes from the equation.

steps.title: Rebalance Annually
steps.content: Once per year, check if any fund is more than 5% off target. Sell the overweight, buy the underweight.

mistakes.solution: Invest consistently regardless of market conditions. Time in market beats timing the market.
Stick to your diversified plan. Individual stocks are gambling, not investing.
The US is only 54% of world market cap. Don't miss global opportunities.
Review quarterly at most. Daily checking leads to emotional decisions.
Annual rebalancing forces you to sell high and buy low automatically.
Keep expense ratios under 0.10%. High fees compound against you forever.

keyTakeaways.title: üéâ Key Takeaways
items: Diversification reduces risk without sacrificing returns
Four funds (ITOT, VXUS, AGG, BNDX) provide global exposure
Keep costs low - under 0.06% annually for the entire portfolio
Automate everything to remove emotion from investing
Rebalance annually to maintain target allocation
Time in the market beats timing the market
Start with whatever you can afford - consistency matters most

nextSteps.title: Next Steps
nextSteps.description: Congratulations! You now have a complete understanding of how to build a diversified portfolio. The next step is to take action - open a brokerage account and start investing with your four-fund foundation.
nextSteps.lessonLabel: Lesson 4 of 4 ‚Äî "Complete! You've mastered portfolio building."
nextSteps.completeMessage: Remember: The best portfolio is the one you can stick with. Start simple, stay consistent, and let time and compound interest work their magic.
